title: Allowing Abundance: A Caregiver Steps Into the Vortex
summary: In a sunlit Tallinn café, three retirees learn to “allow themselves to receive”—from unexpected windfalls to guilt-free self-treats—proving that welcoming abundance completes the energy loop and aligns you with the universe’s joyful flow.
story:
In a sunlit café overlooking Tallinn’s Old Town rooftops, Dr. Liisa Tamm—recently retired physician—sipped chamomile tea with two longtime friends, Mart and Pille. All three hovered around their late sixties, and each had faced financial tight spots after stepping away from full-time work. Today, though, the mood was light.

Mart pushed his cup aside and grinned. “I sold my lakeside summer cottage last month—and you should have seen the joy on my face when the bank transfer hit my account.” He leaned back. “You know, for thirty years I called myself ‘the cautious saver.’ But then I read about this Abraham-Hicks idea: ‘Allow yourself to receive.’ I realized I’d been blocking good things by worrying I didn’t deserve them.”

Pille, formerly an accountant, nodded slowly. “I’ve always been the one tracking every kroon and eurocent, terrified of spending more than necessary. But when I planted the thought that I deserved abundance—truly allowed it to flow—I started noticing little windfalls: a cashback refund, an unexpected gift from a nephew. Each one became proof I could trust receiving.”

Liisa, who’d spent her career caring for patients more than herself, felt her heart flutter. “I’ve always given so much—my time, my energy—and yet I hesitated at the thought of treating myself. Last week, I booked a weekend retreat in Haapsalu. I felt guilty at first, like I didn’t earn that pleasure.” She paused, stirring her tea. “But then I remembered what you two said: ‘If you give love, care, expertise—you must allow yourself to receive the same.’” 

That evening, as Liisa walked through the cobbled streets toward her apartment in Harju County, she realized something profound. She could extend her own nurturing spirit inward. By opening to receive—be it a kind word, financial ease, or peaceful leisure—she wasn’t being selfish. She was completing the circle of energy she had spent a lifetime passing along. 

And in that moment, the soft glow of the streetlamps seemed to wink at her, as if the universe itself were cheering: “Yes, Doctor, you are worthy. Allow yourself to receive.”
